question: Nowadays, some buildings such as offices and school have open space design instead of seperate rooms. Why is it so? Do you think it is a positive development or negative?
text: New era construction prefers casual workspaces rather than private ones in regards to corporate and educational institutions. One of the main reason is, it creates a conducive environment to do the job efficiently. Others being, it improves inter-personal relations with their peers. I definitely support such advancement in infrastructures and will substantiate the same idea in my following essay with relevant examples.

To begin with, any individual, be it a student or an employee, need comfortable and friendly set up, where they can connect with other co-workers and discuss their viewpoints. Subsequently, this facilitates trust and bonding between them, which help to address the pressing issue quickly . For example, In India, in ancient times, Gurukuls were built to provide education in forest area far from home. Children could learn there a lot more than just basic qualification, which in return lead to their overall development as a student.

I certainly agree to it as a positive development as it not only improves one's job efficiency but enhances co-dependence between them. One tends to learn a different perspective of the same issue when discussed it open-heartedly with another colleague which eventually lands into a better outcome and also built trust and confidence. For instance, a lot of start-ups are switching to the open-design concept for building camaraderie and team spirit among their employees.
In conclusion, open workspaces are going to stay for a very long time because it creates a positive environment for students and employees which improves their productivity and team spirit.
